title: How to Childproof a Door Screen

steps.headline: Remove the screen from the metal insert frame.
Cut a section of new screen that fits over the frame.
steps.description: Leave an inch or two (a few centimeters) of overlap.

steps.headline: Cut four rubber splines.
steps.description: Here is where things get interesting. The typical screen insert uses one big length of spline that runs all around the frame. For this project, cut four separate pieces of rubber spline, equal in length to the four frame sides.

steps.headline: Center the screen on the frame as best you can.
steps.description: Use the convex end of the spline tool to press it into the frame groove.

steps.headline: Grab a matching spline piece.
steps.description: Squeeze a drop of hot glue into the groove, and use the spline tool (the concave end) to press the spline down into the groove.

steps.headline: Add more glue further down the groove, and press the spline further into the groove.
steps.description: Continue adding more glue every few inches (or centimeters), until you reach until the end of the frame side. The spline may be longer than you expected, so be prepared to trim it. If you use the utility knife, try to avoid accidentally slicing your new screen; scissors work better.

steps.headline: When the spline is all glued in, lay a bead of glue on top of the spline, all the way back.
steps.description: The spline should be encased in glue.

steps.headline: Repeat for each adjacent side (it can be helpful to go counterclockwise).
Use the Exacto knife to trim excess screen material.
All done!
steps.description: A beautiful screen insert, ready to go back in the door. And hopefully stay there a while.

steps.headline: Be aware that it won't last forever.
steps.description: Here's what the screen looks like when you remove it (pliers are necessary). The one pictured here lasted three years against a cat and two toddlers. You can reuse the spline pieces again when remaking a new screen.

text: Remove the screen from the metal insert frame.  Cut a section of new screen that fits over the frame. Leave an inch or two (a few centimeters) of overlap. Cut four rubber splines. Here is where things get interesting. The typical screen insert uses one big length of spline that runs all around the frame. For this project, cut four separate pieces of rubber spline, equal in length to the four frame sides. Center the screen on the frame as best you can. Use the convex end of the spline tool to press it into the frame groove. Grab a matching spline piece. Squeeze a drop of hot glue into the groove, and use the spline tool (the concave end) to press the spline down into the groove. Add more glue further down the groove, and press the spline further into the groove. Continue adding more glue every few inches (or centimeters), until you reach until the end of the frame side. The spline may be longer than you expected, so be prepared to trim it. If you use the utility knife, try to avoid accidentally slicing your new screen; scissors work better. When the spline is all glued in, lay a bead of glue on top of the spline, all the way back. The spline should be encased in glue. Repeat for each adjacent side (it can be helpful to go counterclockwise).  Use the Exacto knife to trim excess screen material.  All done! A beautiful screen insert, ready to go back in the door. And hopefully stay there a while. Be aware that it won't last forever. Here's what the screen looks like when you remove it (pliers are necessary). The one pictured here lasted three years against a cat and two toddlers. You can reuse the spline pieces again when remaking a new screen.
